headline: How major US stock indexes fared Friday, 2/27/2026
summary: U.S. stocks sank as Wall Street kept punishing companies that could become losers in the AI revolution. A surprisingly discouraging update on inflation also hurt the market Friday, while oil prices climbed along with worries about tensions between the United States and Iran. The S&P 500 fell 0.4% and closed out just its second losing month in the last 10.

headline: Dow Drops 520 Points But Ekes Out 10th Monthly Gain in a Row
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell sharply on Friday, but the index managed to eke out its tenth monthly gain in a row.  The blue-chip index finished 522 points, or 1.1%, lower on Friday.  The S&P 500 fell 0.5%, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.9%.

headline: Even VCs bullish on AI say the SaaS-pocalypse isn't here yet
summary: Block’s layoff of 40% of its workforce on Thursday seemed to confirm some investors’ concerns that AI will take over human jobs not a decade from now, but tomorrow. Alarming scenarios have circulated broadly in recent weeks. Citrini Research’s report outlining a hypothetical 2028 AI-dominated economy painted a picture in which companies like American Express have been gutted by the twin disruptors of agentic AI and stablecoins. Entrepreneur Matt Shumer’s essay “Something Big is Happening” made t

headline: Netflix stock gains on Warner Bros. loss, Jack Dorsey cuts jobs
summary: Yahoo Finance Senior Producer John Hyland tracks Friday's top moving stocks and biggest market stories in this Market Minute. Financials are the latest sector to get hit by artificial intelligence (AI) disruption, with the KBW Nasdaq Bank Index (^BKX) experiencing its worst month since March of last year. Block (XYZ) stock is surging after CEO Jack Dorsey went all in on AI, announcing a 40% cut to the company's workforce. Netflix (NFLX) stock is on the rise after the company dropped its bid to acquire Warner Bros. (WBD). Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

headline: The Dow’s ‘Citrini Selloff’ Is Back. Blame Block.
summary: Block’s mass layoffs reignited Wall Street’s paranoia about artificial intelligence advancements. The Dow fell 588 points, or 1.2%. The S&P 500 was down 0.6%. The Nasdaq Composite was down 0.8%. Among the hardest hit stocks in the Dow were American Express, Goldman Sachs Group, Salesforce, and JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Block to cut workforce by 40%, CEO Jack Dorsey cites AI

Yahoo Finance Technology Editor Dan Howley joins Market Catalysts host Julie Hyman to discuss the move, Block CEO Jack Dorsey's comments about the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) tools, and more. headline: How Jack Dorsey Explained Cutting Almost Half of Block’s Staff
summary: The chairman and co-founder of  Block  is cutting 40% of the payments company’s workforce, or more than 4,000 employees, betting artificial-intelligence tools can fill the gap.  Dorsey said Block, which owns Square and Cash App, is financially sound.  Instead, the tech entrepreneur argues that companies need flatter structures and fewer employees to thrive in the AI era.

summary: Investing.com -- Block Inc (NYSE:SQ) announced Thursday it will reduce its workforce by 40% to embrace what CEO Jack Dorsey called an "AI-native future," less than a week after a dystopian research report on artificial intelligence job displacement went viral and sparked heated debate across financial markets.

headline: Block shares soar as Dorsey leans on AI to trim workforce
summary: Block shares soared more than 20% in premarket trading on Friday after it announced it would nearly ‌halve its workforce as part of an overhaul to embed artificial ‌intelligence tools across its operations.  The layoffs are the most visible signs of how the ​U.S. fintech industry is navigating the impact of AI, with its CEO, tech billionaire Jack Dorsey, warning that most companies were "late" to realize the emerging technology's potential.  "At its core, it's about how some companies may be run ‌going forward – not just ⁠doomsday headcount reductions, but also enabling higher ROI investments in growth and FCF," analysts at Evercore ISI wrote, referring ⁠to free cash flow.

raw.headline: Block shares soar as Dorsey leans on AI to trim workforce

"At its core, it's about how some companies may be run ‌going forward – not just ⁠doomsday headcount reductions, but also enabling higher ROI investments in growth and FCF," analysts at Evercore ISI wrote, referring ⁠to free cash flow.

headline: AI Job Cuts Drive 11% WiseTech, 23% Block Share Surge
summary: This article first appeared on GuruFocus.  Morningstar analysts are warning that the AI narrative running through markets may be tilting more toward cost destruction than value creation.  In a note Thursday, analyst Lochlan Halloway wrote that investors appear squarely focused on what artificial intelligence might eliminate, rather than the incremental value it could unlock.

raw.summary: This article first appeared on GuruFocus.  Morningstar analysts are warning that the AI narrative running through markets may be tilting more toward cost destruction than value creation.  In a note Thursday, analyst Lochlan Halloway wrote that investors appear squarely focused on what artificial intelligence might eliminate, rather than the incremental value it could unlock.

headline: Block shares jump as CEO Jack Dorsey links major job cuts to AI
summary: CNBC's MacKenzie Sigalos reports on Block’s sweeping workforce reduction, a roughly 40% cut that CEO Jack Dorsey is explicitly linking to AI, and why investors are rewarding the move even as the quarter itself came in largely in line, betting that deeper efficiency and stronger profit margins are starting to emerge at a still-growing, already-profitable company.

headline: US stock futures falter on AI jitters, Nasdaq braces for steep monthly fall
summary: U.S. stock index futures slid on Friday as growing AI unease weighed on technology stocks, with the Nasdaq staring at its steepest monthly drop since March 2025, ‌and investors awaited key inflation data later in the day. Technology stocks saw immense turbulence this month ‌due to AI concerns, even as investors fretted about the payoff from massive planning spending on artificial-intelligence technology. Brewing tariff uncertainty also ​stoked volatility after the U.S. Supreme Court last week voided most of the duties U.S. President Donald Trump imposed last year.

headline: Fintech company Block lays off 4,000 of its 10,000 staff, citing gains from AI
summary: Shares in the financial technology company Block have soared more than 20% in after-hours trading after its CEO announced it was laying off more than 4,000 of its 10,000 some employees due to its use of artificial intelligence.  Dorsey's comments explicitly naming AI as a key driver behind the move were also posted on X, or Twitter, a company he co-founded.  Block’s shares gained 5% Thursday to $54.53, before it reported its earnings.

headline: Australia's Appen says being the Switzerland of AI boosts demand for its human testing
summary: Australia's Appen, a big supplier of human assessment of artificial intelligence systems, said rising technology protectionism would boost demand ‌in the United States and China for its services that use ‌real people to train and test models.  While automation ​drives mass layoffs at some businesses such as WiseTech and Block, demand is rising for companies that supply the human input needed to develop and refine AI.  Tech protectionism, which has already prompted Washington to restrict Nvidia AI chip exports to China, ‌could give rise to trade ⁠barriers in data, model sourcing and verification, forcing companies to develop these locally, Appen's CEO said.

raw.headline: Australia's Appen says being the Switzerland of AI boosts demand for its human testing
raw.summary: Australia's Appen, a big supplier of human assessment of artificial intelligence systems, said rising technology protectionism would boost demand ‌in the United States and China for its services that use ‌real people to train and test models.  While automation ​drives mass layoffs at some businesses such as WiseTech and Block, demand is rising for companies that supply the human input needed to develop and refine AI.  Tech protectionism, which has already prompted Washington to restrict Nvidia AI chip exports to China, ‌could give rise to trade ⁠barriers in data, model sourcing and verification, forcing companies to develop these locally, Appen's CEO said.
